comment._content:
Gee, guess what the insurance would not cover?
[assuming that it would have even have been available]
Fire theft & collision?
First: Collision with what... a pier, another boat or jet-ski a buoy, a swimmer in addition to collision with a car or land-based property.
Capsizing, sinking, leak damage, fire.
Drowning perhaps in combination to collision.
Theft - Report as a stolen car or a boat?
If you are an underwriter, does your boss hate
you so much that he would have you work on
something like this?

comment.author: 75490765@N04
comment._content:
Those were the crazy Sixties, when it was okay to be different and experimental, even admirable, and exciting. No-one whined about the possible implications for the environment caused by the use of such vehicles, or the impact of gender-role stereotyping and marginalization of women due to the mass-media depiction and validation of male drivers in an ongoing patriarchal hegemony situation. 

Anyway... the Amphicar had the same problem of most vehicles that tried to be dual-mode; it compromised, and did neither task well. There was a VW equivalent, too. Problem: they just couldn't cope in rough water.

In any case, this is a superb and evocative pic, the best kind of B&W photojournalism from the days when newspapers were worth reading,
